Headline.Para: WALL STREET INSIGHT; Trump slump back in focus, Dow in correction territory

LeadPara.Para: THE so-called "Trump Slump" returned last week as broad indexes saw their biggest losses in more than two years because of trade-war fears.

This week, markets may recoil from more economic threats between the United States and China or military threats between the US and Iran, while Treasury yields and housing data could also provide nasty surprises.

TailParas.Para: The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average index fell by more than 5 per cent on the week for its worst week since January 2016, closing at its lowest point of the year, at 23,533.

The Dow is now back in correction territory, being more than 10 per cent below its January high. The next major milestone on the way down would be bear-market territory - still more than 2,000 points away.
While most strategists say the rout is unlikely to go that far, there is little doubt that a prolonged slowdown in trade would have dire consequences for the economy and the stock market.

Despite near-unanimous warnings from economists about the risks to global trade, US President Donald Trump followed up earlier plans for tariffs on steel and aluminium by promising to slap tariffs on US$60 billion worth of Chinese imports.
That caused a plunge in the share prices of major US exporters such as machinery makers Caterpillar and Deere and aircraft manufacturer Boeing.
The response from Beijing came swiftly, with vows to meet the tariffs with levies on imports of US steel, pork and other products.
Fears that the trade war would spiral out of control caused a sell-off in markets for soyabeans and grain, which US farmers ship to China.
"Trade wars are akin to zero-sum games or mutually assured destruction. In the long run no-one really wins!" said strategists at brokerage Jefferies, in a research note.
Investors withdrew US$17.5 billion of cash from US equity exchange-traded funds on the week, suggesting a major pullback from risk.

A controversy about Facebook's data security after personal data was reportedly leaked to Cambridge Analytica without permission weighed on one of the highest risk/highest-return stock market sectors, information technology.
In another sign of investors' discomfort with risky investments, safe havens such as Treasury bonds, the Japanese yen and gold rose.
Markets were rattled last Wednesday during Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's first policy statement and press conference.

While Mr Powell did not signal any immediate fears about economic growth or inflation, he hinted that the central bank was determined to hike rates aggressively this year, even as it braced for a potential slowdown in trade.
"It adds up to cross currents of uncertainty," said Quincy Krosby, chief market strategist at Prudential Financial.
Ms Krosby said that Mr Trump appeared to be using the tariff threats to stake out a negotiating position for a more peaceful resolution of trade imbalances with China.
Another strategist said there was a precedent for such brass-knuckle trade negotiations.

"The base case is that the cycle is reminiscent of the late 1980s stand-off between (former US president) Ronald Reagan and the Japanese," said the Jefferies strategists. "Ultimately, the Japanese became a big investor in US car manufacturing. Expect a deal to be done."
Aside from trade wars, the primary market fear remains inflation and Treasury yields.
By expressing confidence about economic growth and concerns about inflation, Mr Powell underscored fears about a Fed that's gearing up for a series of price-controlling rate hikes.
The Fed's stance has made investors "hyper-sensitive" to signs of inflation, Ms Krosby said.

There's another source of fuel for rising yields, however. Last Friday, Bloomberg News reported that the Chinese are considering responding to the Trump administration's threat of tariffs by slowing down Treasury purchases.

As the largest overseas holder of Treasurys, China has the power to sway the Treasury market. Most strategists argue that China has no interest in destabilising the US economy or its bond market, however.
"They can slow down their purchases, of course, but slowing down purchases versus selling everything - that's a major leap," noted Ms Krosby.

The main threat to global economic growth is any slowdown in trade resulting from the spat between the US and China. But there are other risks, including signs that the US housing market is over-heating.
Last week, the National Association of Realtors reported a surprise decline in January new-home sales.
That data confirmed fears that home buyers are retreating in the face of rising home prices and mortgage rates.
This week expect statistics from S&P Case Shiller and the Commerce Department on house prices and pending home sales, respectively.
Oil futures were among the few commodities that gained in value last week. Oil traders were betting that the US would take a more bellicose stance on Iran and North Korea. It's a safe bet.
The most bellicose diplomat in recent US history, John Bolton, is Mr Trump's appointee to take over as national security adviser.

Mr Bolton is an avowed opponent of re-committing to the nuclear deal with Iran. Oil traders, as well as stock traders, will be watching for reactions to Mr Bolton's appointment both in Washington and in Iran.
